overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students consider how to simulate an experiment. They use coin tosses to simulate three friends being assigned to the same water slide and summarize the results in a probability model. Using the same context, they construct a tree diagram to list all outcomes and calculate the theoretical probabilities. Students use tree diagrams to create probability models for spinning a spinner twice and guessing on a three-question test.

overview_item_data_items: I can construct a probability model and use it to determine probabilities.
I can construct a tree diagram to determine the theoretical probability of an event.
I can construct and interpret a non-uniform probability model.
You can simulate situations that involve more than one event to calculate experimental probabilities.
You can use a tree diagram to create an organized list and determine the possible outcomes when a situation includes more than one event.
At the end of each branch of a tree diagram, identify how it relates to the probability question to create a list of the possible outcomes.
To calculate probability, you can create a tree diagram, list the outcomes, then construct and use a probability model to respond to the question.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students describe how they would simulate an event.
Students calculate the theoretical probability of three friends being assigned to the same water slide.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Using Tree Diagrams to Determine Probabilities
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students use a tree diagram to list the possible outcomes of spinning a 5-sided spinner twice.
Students create a tree diagram to list the possible outcomes for guessing the answers to a true-false test.
